title: Tomas Lindahl, Paul Modrich and Aziz Sancar to receive Nobel Prize in chemistry for 2015
text:
Tomas Lindahl, Paul Modrich and Aziz Sancar to receive Nobel Prize in chemistry for 2015 8 October 2015 Print Email 
The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 2015 to Tomas Lindahl, Paul Modrich and Aziz Sancar for their molecular-level experiment showing how cells repair damaged DNA and safeguard the genetic information. 
The scientist trio have provided fundamental insights into the functions of cells, which can be used in the development of new cancer treatments. 
Tomas Lindahl is a Swedish citizen who was born in 1938. He completed his PhD from Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden in 1967. 
Between 1978 and 82, Lindahl served at the University of Gothenburg as a professor of Medical and Physiological Chemistry. 
Currently, he is serving as Emeritus group leader at the Francis Crick Institute, and Emeritus director of Cancer Research UK at Clare Hall Laboratory, Hertfordshire, UK. 
US citizen Paul Modrich was born 1946. He did his PhD at Stanford University, Stanford, US in 1973, and is presently working as an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, and James B Duke professor of Biochemistry at Duke University School of Medicine, Durham, USA. "The scientist trio have provided fundamental insights into the functions of cells, which can be used in the development of new cancer treatments." 
US citizen Aziz Sancar did his PhD at the University of Texas, US in 1977. 
At present Sancar is serving as Sarah Graham Kenan professor of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of North Carolina School of Medicine, Chapel Hill, US. He was born in 1946 in Savur, Turkey. 
Tomas Lindahl, through his research, demonstrated the instable and decaying quality of DNA molecules, against the popular belief that DNA is an extremely stable molecule. 
Based on this insight, Lindahl discovered a molecular machinery, base excision repair, which constantly counteracts the collapse of our DNA. 
Aziz Sancar has mapped nucleotide excision repair. This mechanism has been used by cells to repair UV damage to DNA. If people are born with defects in this repair system, they have tendency to develop skin cancer when exposed to sunlight. 
Paul Modrich has showed the mismatch repair of cells that occurs when DNA is replicated during cell division, which reduces error frequency a thousand times. 
Inborn defects in mismatch repair are known to cause a hereditary variant of colon cancer.
